Issues.Title: Ivy LS: autocompletion TCB fixture for top-level expression context
Issues.Body:
Autocompleting in a top-level context (e.g. completing at `{{|}}`) is challenging, because it merges several different namespaces. The user could be attempting to refer to a component property, a variable defined at the current template level or above, a template reference (again at the current level or above), or certain "special" identifiers like `$any`. In event contexts, they might also be referring to the `$event` variable.

The compiler should offer an API to complete a top-level context expression, independently of template position, to allow the LS to provide an autocompletion experience in such contexts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy LS: autocompletion TCB fixture for top-level expression context" (#38598)

Issues.Title: Ivy LS: Template parser produces ASTs for invalid templates
Issues.Body:
A central issue with autocompletion is that frequently, completion is requested when the template is not strictly valid. For example, the user may attempt to complete the expression `foo.`, where the template parser expects an identifier, but none is present prior to the completion.

To allow for the best possible autocompletion experience, the template parser should still be able to produce ASTs for templates that are "invalid" in certain ways.

A few scenarios here stand out:

1) incomplete property access expressions

`{{foo.}}` should parse to an AST, even though it will (rightfully) produce an error about the expected identifier.

Ideally, this AST has a `PropertyRead` with an empty name, which the type-checking engine can use to generate correct auto-completion code.

2) missing interpolation closing tag

`{{foo` should parse to an AST, even though it also produces an error about the missing interpolation ending tag `}}`.

3) incomplete element tag

`<foo` should parse to an AST, even though the element start closing marker `>` is missing. For example, `<foo<bar></bar>` should probably be interpreted as `<foo></foo><bar></bar>`. This will allow for autocompletion of tag names.

4) incomplete property/event bindings

`<foo [` and `<foo [input` should both parse to ASTs, even without expressions that follow or the closing `]`. The same goes for event bindings.

5) unclosed values

`<foo [bar]="...` - this one is very tricky, since it's completely ambiguous where the expression is supposed to end. We might be able to cheat here and look at the cursor position, and attempt a parse that assumes a closing quote at the cursor position if the original parse results in unbalanced quotes. This is an "advanced" case and might be better left for future efforts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Ivy LS: Template parser produces ASTs for invalid templates" (#38596)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler-cli): cleanup after TS 4.0 changes
Issues.Body:
This commit extracts some TS 4.0 sensitive operations into utility functions
to better isolate them from the rest of the code base. This way, support for
3.9-specific functionality is isolated to a single location, and cleanup
after removal of 3.9 support will be much more straightforward.

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): add missing types field in package.json
Issues.Body:
Close #38584

In zone.js 0.11.1, the `types` field is missing in the `package.json`,
the reason is in zone.js 0.11.0, the `files` field is used to specify the
types, but it cause the npm package not contain any bundles issue, so zone.js
0.11.1 remove the `files` field, which cause the `type` definition gone.

This PR concat the `zone.js.d.ts`, `zone.configurations.api.ts`, `zone.api.extensions.ts`
types into a single `zone.js.d.ts` file.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(zone.js): add missing types field in package.json" (#38585)

Issues.Title: docs(forms): exclude internal-only methods and properties from docs
Issues.Body:
Prior to this commit, a lot of internal-only class properties and methods (such as `ngOnChanges`)
of the Forms package directives were exposed on angular.io website. These fields are not expected
to be called externally (they are used/invoked by framework only), since they are part of internal
implementations of the following interfaces:

* Angular lifecycle hook interfaces
* ControlValueAccessor interface
* Validator interface

Having these internal-only fields in docs creates unnecessary noise on directive detail pages.
This commit adds the `@nodoc` annotation to these properties and methods to keep fields in the
golden files, but hide them in docs.

## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

- [x] Documentation content changes


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs(forms): exclude internal-only methods and properties from docs" (#38583)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): allow transformation of i18n extraction builder configuration
Issues.Body:
This change allows the underlying webpack configuration of the i18n extraction builder to be modified when programmatically using the builder.  This change also aligns the i18n extraction builder with the other Webpack-based builders in the package.
Programmatic usage of the `@angular-devkit/build-angular` builders is currently considered experimental.

Closes #16679
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): allow transformation of i18n extraction builder configuration" (#18613)

Issues.Title: Referenced projects must have the new composite setting enabled
Issues.Body:
## Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] new - [x] generate ### Description The typescript docs say (https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/project-references.html): > Referenced projects must have the new composite setting enabled. and the solutions-style project generated by angular-cli does not have the composite setting enabled. The documentation might be wrong, idk, but **must** is pretty unambiguous. It seems that tsc does compile, but it might have other impacts (performance, ide features not working, just guessing at that point) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ``` npx ng new superduper cd superduper npx ng generate library foo egrep -r composite *json projects/foo/*json ``` ## üåç Your Environment 

$ npx ng version

     _                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|
   / ‚ñ≥ \ | '_ \ / _` | | | | |/ _` | '__|   | |   | |    | |
  / ___ \| | | | (_| | |_| | | (_| | |      | |___| |___ | |
 /_/   \_\_| |_|\__, |\__,_|_|\__,_|_|       \____|_____|___|
                |___/

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/architect): support async generator based builders
Issues.Body: "Watch" type builders (builders with more than one result) can now be implemented as async generator functions. This allows such a builder to be more easily implemented in cases where an upstream API is async iterator/generator based or when async generators are the preferred method of implementation.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "feat(@angular-devkit/architect): support async generator based builders" (#18611)

Issues.Title: Wrong  parameter name of CanActivate guard.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [x] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description According to the document of [CanActivate](https://angular.io/api/router/CanActivate) interface, the parameters of `canActivate` is ```typescript canActivate( route: ActivatedRouteSnapshot, state: RouterStateSnapshot): Observable | Promise | boolean | UrlTree ``` But the parameters of the generated guard file is ```typescript canActivate( next: ActivatedRouteSnapshot, //~~~~ //should be "route" state: RouterStateSnapshot): Observable | Promise | boolean | UrlTree { return true; } ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. `ng new guard-impl-demo --defaults` 2. `cd guard-impl-demo` 3. `ng generate guard auth --implements CanActivate` ## üåç Your Environment 


     _                      _                 ____ _     ___
    / \   _ __   __ _ _   _| | __ _ _ __     / ___| |   |_ _|

Issues.Title: SCSS sourcemaps for component scss fail in Safari
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Description Safari does not correctly use SCSS source maps ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Simple steps to reproduce this bug. 1. Create a new project with `new new` and scss. 2. Add styles to `styles.scss` 3. import another scss partial into `styles.scss`, 3. generate a component and add style rules to the component's scss file. You can find a simple project with only this here: https://github.com/smlombardi/scss-cli-test 4. run the project. 5. Inspect the three headers in dev tools in Chrome. You can see the originating scss file where each rule lives, as expected ![chrome styles scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228147-c1249e80-e6f5-11ea-959c-eb30dd5d0788.jpg) ![chrome include scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228165-c8e44300-e6f5-11ea-9897-69cd77854828.jpg) ![chrome component scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228173-cc77ca00-e6f5-11ea-8f17-6f3272ac6b3b.jpg) 6. Try the same inspection in Safari. The component SCSS is not identified: ![safari styles scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228382-24163580-e6f6-11ea-8b18-355165fb0f12.jpg) ![safari include scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228386-25476280-e6f6-11ea-8fb7-03de0db91cf0.jpg) ![safari component scss](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/91228391-27112600-e6f6-11ea-8bf6-c31c511c4dfe.jpg) This has been like this as long as I can remember, I keep hoping newer versions of the CLI will fix this so I can use Safari for scss development. You can see my angular.json config at the repo or directly here: https://github.com/smlombardi/scss-cli-test/blob/master/angular.json ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: @angular-devkit/build-optimizer strips non-Angular decorators
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I understood from the description of the build-optimizer plugin, that non-Angular decorators should _not_ be stripped. https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular-devkit/build-optimizer However, I can see that decorated properties inside the constructor are removed, which prevents my team from using build-optimizer as part of the `ng build` command (we use inversifyjs to manage our dependencies outside of the Angular module). Inside `scrub-file.ts`, the `isDecorateAssignmentExpression` method seems to be responsible for the decision to strip this metadata. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/kevindrecruit/angular-build-optimizer-issue ## üî• Exception or Error Using the minimum reproduction git repository, we can see the following error (_which is specific to _inversifyjs__): ``` ERROR Error: Missing required @inject or @multiInject annotation in: argument 0 in class e. ``` The point is that the `@inject()` has been removed from the constructor where it is still needed. ## üåç Your Environment

### Description

I'm using solutions style tsconfig to add types for scripts.

// tsconfig.json
```json
{
  "files": [],
  "references": [
    {
      "path": "./projects/my-app/tsconfig.app.json"
```

```json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "strict": true,
    "target": "ESNext",

    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "types": ["node"],
    "allowJs": true
  },
  "include": ["./extra-webpack.config.ts","./build-script.ts"]
}

```
Update to ng 10.1 remove my solutions style tsconfig. So "./tsconfig.scripts.json" will not work after update to 10.1.0-next.7

Issues.Title: Uncaught TypeError: Object prototype may only be an Object or null: undefined
Issues.Body:
Build config `"buildOptimizer": true` when `"optimization": true` in angular.json file breaks my project on production build while using angular 10. On Angular 9 everything works perfect. Also if it is set to false, production build is working as it should.
Stacktrace in browser after opening project: 
```
main.143e43602909445d220b.js:1 Uncaught TypeError: Object prototype may only be an Object or null: undefined
    at setPrototypeOf (<anonymous>)
    at i (main.143e43602909445d220b.js:1)
    at r (main.143e43602909445d220b.js:1)
    at main.143e43602909445d220b.js:1
    at Object.l0Em (main.143e43602909445d220b.js:1)
    at l (runtime.c51bd5b1c616d9ffddc1.js:1)
```

Issues.Title: Dev code not being stripped in prod builds
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Problem occurs in at least Angular 9 and 10. ### Description This issue is a follow-up to [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63415056/angular-tree-shaking-not-stripping-dev-code-what-things-should-i-look-for). The question received some upvotes but no answers to the problem, so I'm asking here because I'm really not sure what to do. The short version is that code gated by compile-time constants like below is not being stripped in prod builds in my project, and I have no idea what to look at to figure out why. I don't know if it's a bug in Angular or a problem in my code. How can I figure out the issue? Any help that can point me in the right direction would be tremendously appreciated. I'm using this code in `main.ts` (just for testing, the actual code I need stripped is in a component): ```ts if (environment.production) { console.warn('this is a prod build'); enableProdMode(); } if (!environment.production) { console.warn('this is a dev build'); } ``` And this code is output as the result of the prod build: ```js s.X.production&&(console.warn("this is a prod build"),Object(i.R)()),s.X.production||console.warn("this is a dev build") ``` Other code:
environment.prod.ts

`environment.ts` is exactly the same, just with `false` instead of `true`. ```ts export const environment = { production: true }; export * from './services/services'; ```

Relevant part of angular.json

```json "my-prod-config": { "optimization": true, "outputHashing": "all", "sourceMap": false, "extractCss": true, "namedChunks": false, "aot": true, "extractLicenses": true, "vendorChunk": false, "buildOptimizer": true, "stylePreprocessorOptions": { "includePaths": [ "src/styles" ] }, "fileReplacements": [ { "replace": "src/environments/environment.ts", "with": "src/environments/environment.prod.ts" } ], "baseHref": "./" } ```

tsconfig.base.json

```json { "compileOnSave": false, "compilerOptions": { "downlevelIteration": true, "importHelpers": true, "module": "es2020", "outDir": "./dist/out-tsc", "sourceMap": true, "declaration": false, "moduleResolution": "node", "baseUrl": "src/", "experimentalDecorators": true, "allowJs": true, "target": "es2015", "lib": [ "es2018", "dom" ], "paths": { "path1": [ "app/modules/stripped-from-stack-overflow-example1" ], "path2": [ "app/modules/stripped-from-stack-overflow-example2" ] } }, "files": [ "src/main.ts", "src/polyfills.ts" ], "angularCompilerOptions": { "fullTemplateTypeCheck": true, "strictTemplates": true, "strictInjectionParameters": true } } ```

package.json

```json { "name": "my-app", "version": "0.0.0", "license": "MIT", "scripts": { "section stripped": "section stripped" }, "private": true, "dependencies": { "@angular/animations": "10.0.8", "@angular/common": "10.0.8", "@angular/compiler": "10.0.8", "@angular/core": "10.0.8", "@angular/forms": "10.0.8", "@angular/platform-browser": "10.0.8", "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "10.0.8", "@angular/router": "10.0.8", "@ng-idle/core": "9.0.0-beta.1", "@ng-idle/keepalive": "9.0.0-beta.1", "@ngneat/until-destroy": "8.0.1", "angular-svg-icon": "10.0.0", "brace": "0.11.1", "caniuse-lite": "1.0.30001111", "core-js": "3.6.5", "css-vars-ponyfill": "2.3.2", "detect-browser": "5.1.1", "element-closest-polyfill": "1.0.2", "fomantic-ui": "2.8.6", "moment": "2.24.0", "ngx-drag-drop": "2.0.0", "rxjs": "6.6.2", "tslib": "2.0.0", "typeface-roboto": "0.0.75", "uuid": "8.3.0", "zone.js": "0.10.3" }, "devDependencies": { "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "0.1000.5", "@angular/cli": "10.0.5", "@angular/compiler-cli": "10.0.8", "@angular/language-service": "10.0.8", "@types/uuid": "8.0.1", "codelyzer": "6.0.0", "rimraf": "3.0.2", "rxjs-tslint-rules": "4.34.0", "ts-node": "8.10.2", "tslint": "6.1.3", "tslint-angular": "3.0.2", "typescript": "3.9.7", "webpack-bundle-analyzer": "3.8.0" } } ```

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction I am actively trying to come up with a reproduction right now, but it's difficult because I'm just guessing at what things to try. This exact setup in a new app generated with `ng new` does work, the dev code is stripped. ## üî• Exception or Error N/A ## üåç Your Environment ``` Angular CLI: 10.0.6 Node: 12.18.1 OS: win32 x64 Angular: 10.0.10 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic ... router Ivy Workspace: Yes Package Version ----------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1000.6 @angular-devkit/build-angular 0.1000.6 @angular-devkit/build-optimizer 0.1000.6 @angular-devkit/build-webpack 0.1000.6 @angular-devkit/core 10.0.6 @angular-devkit/schematics 10.0.6 @angular/cli 10.0.6 @ngtools/webpack 10.0.6 @schematics/angular 10.0.6 @schematics/update 0.1000.6 rxjs 6.6.2 typescript 3.9.7 webpack 4.43.0 ``` ## Anything else relevant? * If it helps, something seems to be very wrong with optimization. [Here's a screenshot of our bundle stats.](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/771134/91058484-81c35880-e5f6-11ea-81be-715fa7d6ff71.png) The largest `index.ts` there has [a parsed size of 373 KB](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/771134/91063473-0bc1f000-e5fc-11ea-8599-dd8ca8a0ec0e.png), but it contains nothing other than interfaces, several enums, and several const enums. They are small enums and there are only a few, the vast majority of things in this barrel are interfaces (and none of the interfaces reference classes of any kind). This exact same project using Angular 9 instead of 10 makes that barrel 20 KB instead of 373 KB. * I think this is probably a separate issue because it's only a problem in Angular 10, whereas dev code isn't stripped in 9 or 10, but I'm mentioning it just in case. * Code bounded with `if (false) { }` is properly stripped. * Removing the services export from the end of `environment{.prod}.ts` does not fix the problem. * All CommonJS dependencies were removed, the CLI no longer complains about them, but the problem persists.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dev code not being stripped in prod builds" (#18603)

Issues.Title: Live Reload not working with WSL 2
Issues.Body:
#18002 üêû Bug report ### Command - [x] serve ### Is this a regression? No ### Description I recently "upgraded" my Windows Subsystem for Linux from v1 to v2. I now have two major problems that only occur in my WSL shell. 1. Live reload no longer works. I imagine this has something to do with the new Linux kernel they added in v2. 2. `ng serve` takes approx. 10 to 15 times longer than it did with WSL 1. This may be an issue that belongs in the WSL repo but I figured it was worth bringing up here. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Simple steps to reproduce this bug. 1. Install WSL 2. 2. Create a new Angular project. 3. From your bash shell run `ng serve` or `npm start`. 4. Change a file and notice the CLI doesn't recompile and the browser doesn't reload. ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: Support & Feature request : Add ngc compile single file api for vite/snowpack
Issues.Body:
I have wrote a POC demo for using [vite](https://github.com/vitejs/vite) with Angular: https://github.com/xiaoxiangmoe/vite-ng-app-demo
In demo, it combines `ngc --watch` and `vite serve` by `concurrently`.
If we want  to write a vite-plugin-angular. We may need ngc to compile single file.related issue: https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/37585 Ôºå https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/20422#issuecomment-636075898


In the future, we may be able to provide functions such as hmr based on vite.
Moreover, we may be able to provide snowpack plugins based on the same API.

related issue: https://github.com/vitejs/vite/issues/543

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/table): revert breaking constructor changes
Issues.Body:
In #19964 and #19750 some breaking constructor changes were made which eventually got released as a part of a patch branch which doesn't follow our breaking changes policy.

These changes make the new constructor parameters optional and add fallbacks to the old behavior.

Fixes #20422.

cc @kseamon @MichaelJamesParsons

Issues.Title: bug(CdkTable): CdkTable constructor parameters changed in a patch version
Issues.Body:
The constructor parameters of CdkTable changed in version 10.1.2 (see: https://github.com/angular/components/compare/10.1.1...10.1.2#diff-86c33ad9a24e48674baaf250f4035a11). 

**This issue might be not considered a bug if we do not assume CDK components API is something that should conform semver versioning.** 
However, in my opinion, parameters of a public constructor should be rather treated as a part of the public API. Especially for a CDK, which is meant to be used and extended by others. Thus such a breaking change should be done in major versions only according to the semver standard. 

The particular breaking change:
https://github.com/angular/components/commit/71a2a171b8abb926631045b616483878ac326592#diff-86c33ad9a24e48674baaf250f4035a11R430

The change causes our Barista library to fail the compilation. However, I've originally spotted the problem during development of our product that uses the Barista lib and it was much more cumbersome, because there was no compilation error - the library was already prebuilt and the only error that we got was a runtime one (both Jest and browser):
```
    TypeError: Cannot read property 'nativeElement' of null

      at DtTable.CdkTable (../src/cdk/table/table.ts:442:24)
      at DtTable._DtTableBase [as constructor] (libs/barista-components/table/src/base-table.ts:64:5)
      at new DtTable (libs/barista-components/table/src/table.ts:166:5)
      at createClass (../packages/core/src/view/provider.ts:290:7)
      at createDirectiveInstance (../packages/core/src/view/provider.ts:142:7)
      at createViewNodes (../packages/core/src/view/view.ts:314:28)
      at callViewAction (../packages/core/src/view/view.ts:647:7)
      at execComponentViewsAction (../packages/core/src/view/view.ts:570:7)
      at createViewNodes (../packages/core/src/view/view.ts:342:3)
      at createRootView (../packages/core/src/view/view.ts:216:3)
      at callWithDebugContext (../packages/core/src/view/services.ts:638:23)
      at Object.debugCreateRootView [as createRootView] (../packages/core/src/view/services.ts:119:10)
      at ComponentFactory_.create (../packages/core/src/view/refs.ts:92:27)
      at initComponent (../packages/core/testing/src/test_bed.ts:618:28)
      at ZoneDelegate.invoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:386:30)
      at ProxyZoneSpec.onInvoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/proxy.js:117:43)
      at ZoneDelegate.invoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:385:36)
      at Object.onInvoke (../packages/core/src/zone/ng_zone.ts:326:29)
      at ZoneDelegate.invoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:385:36)
      at Zone.run (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:143:47)
      at NgZone.run (../packages/core/src/zone/ng_zone.ts:180:50)
      at TestBedViewEngine.createComponent (../packages/core/testing/src/test_bed.ts:622:56)
      at Function.TestBedViewEngine.createComponent (../packages/core/testing/src/test_bed.ts:245:36)
      at libs/cmc/home/feature/src/lib/network-zones/details/table/cmc-network-zone-details-table.component.spec.ts:92:23
      at ZoneDelegate.invoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:386:30)
      at ProxyZoneSpec.onInvoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/proxy.js:117:43)
      at ZoneDelegate.invoke (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:385:36)
      at Zone.run (node_modules/zone.js/dist/zone.js:143:47)
```
 
As far as I researched, a similar issue was closed: #20308, however Angular 10.0.10 doesn't seem to solve this specific issue. 

#### Reproduction

Real world reproduction example:
1. Clone our open source component library: https://github.com/dynatrace-oss/barista
1. Install dependencies and build it:
  ```npm install && npm run build```
  The build should pass fine.
1. Update the `@angular/cdk` dependency
1. Re-install dependencies and rebuild it - the build will fail:
  ```
ERROR in libs/barista-components/table/src/base-table.ts:64:5 - error TS2554: Expected 8 arguments, but got 7.
 64     super(
 65       differs,
...
 71       platform,
 72     );
```

It can be easily reproduced with a Stackblitz example as well. Please, let me know if you'd like that. Although, I don't think it's necessary - the issue can be easily spotted even with a static analysis. 

#### Expected Behavior

Patch version should not contain API breaking changes.


#### Actual Behavior

The constructor parameter change causes compilation errors in the library using the CDK directly, and runtime errors for projects using it indirectly by a precompiled dependency.


#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.12
- CDK/Material: 10.1.3

Issues.Title: feat(MatFormField): Expose control property
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

I'd like to use a public reference to property `control`.

#### Use Case

Currently I'm working on a dynamic way to show validation messages and so I'm injecting `MatFormField` into the constructor in order to get the control reference, however the property is prefixed by `_`, which implies that should not be used by consumers.

That's one use case, but I can see others and I see several people relying on the `_control` at the moment.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(MatFormField): Expose control property" (#20421)

Issues.Title: MatTab: Provide option to preserve material tab content when switching tabs
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Provide option to preserve material tab content when user is switching tabs (do not reinstantiate content) in material tab group.

#### Use Case

Use cases are well described here:
https://github.com/angular/components/issues/16065

For example a list of items as a first tab and details opening in the other tabs.
Often detail tab is an edit form, state of which consists of model state and some temporary form state - I really would need to avoid persisting all that.

At least for me preserving behavior is more intuitive and expected when it comes to thinking of how tabs are used.
So please at least document your chosen behavior.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "MatTab: Provide option to preserve material tab content when switching tabs" (#20420)

Issues.Title: MatDrawer: Have to tap list-item in sidenav twice on mobile when opened with HammerJS gesture
Issues.Body:
I have a material sidenav in my web-app which I can also open with the HammerJS swipe-right gesture. However, when openend with the gesture, I have to tap twice on a list-item in the sidenav to perform the attached action (click, routerLink).

#### Reproduction
I tried to reproduce this problem on stackblitz with a similar setup, but for some reasons it seems to work in the stackblitz.
[Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-mdnx12?file=src/app/example-component.css)
But maybe someone has a similar setup and experienced the same problem.

Steps to reproduce:
1. Import MatDrawerModule
2. Import HammerJS
3. Create mat-sidenav
4. Attach swipe-right gesture to mat-sidenav-content
4. Swipe the mat-sidenav open and tap on a list-item with a click-event or routerLink
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Performing the action on the list-item with a single tap, even when the sidenav is opened through gestures

#### Actual Behavior

Having to tap twice on the list-item to perform the attached event


#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.1
- CDK/Material: 10.0.0
- Browser(s): Chrome, Chrome-Android
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, Android

This problem occurs on Android phones with Chrome as well as on Chrome for Windows when simulating phone behaviour in the developer tools.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "MatDrawer: Have to tap list-item in sidenav twice on mobile when opened with HammerJS gesture" (#20419)

Issues.Title: test: reduce reliance on static queries
Issues.Body: When Ivy issues were first being resolved in the repo, we accumulated a lot of static queries in tests which we generally shouldn't be depending on. These changes clean up most of the ones that don't require much refactoring to clean up. I'll make some follow-up changes for the trickier ones once these changes land.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "test: reduce reliance on static queries" (#20405)

Issues.Title: perf(drag-drop): bind fewer touchmove listeners
Issues.Body:
On touch devices we have to bind the `touchmove` event before dragging has started, because iOS Safari won't allow us to call `preventDefault` on it otherwise. We also bind another `touchmove` listener once dragging starts which is what is used for moving the elements around on the screen.

These changes remove the dynamically-added `touchmove` listener and use the persistent one for everything instead.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "perf(drag-drop): bind fewer touchmove listeners" (#20404)

Issues.Title: bug(form-field): userAriaDescribedBy type error
Issues.Body:
### Issue Summary

For some reason `userAriaDescribedBy` was showing up as an object in one of our internal tests. This meant that the call to `userAriaDescribedBy.split` threw errors and caused that test to fail.

### Temporary Fix

Our temporary fix is to check the type of `userAriaDescribedBy` to ensure calling `.split` does not throw any errors.

https://github.com/angular/components/pull/20401

### Desired Solution

Figure out where the gap in type checking is and close it so that we don't need to check the type of `userAriaDescribedBy` here.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(form-field): userAriaDescribedBy type error" (#20403)
